<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">


<div style="font-family:Times New Roman;">

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Item 4.
Controls and Procedures</font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-autospace:none;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Evaluation of Disclosure Controls
and Procedures</font></i></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-autospace:none;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Based on an
evaluation under the supervision and with the participation of the Company&#146;s
management, the Company&#146;s principal executive officer and principal financial
officer have concluded that the Company&#146;s disclosure controls and procedures as
defined&#160; in rules 13a-15(e) and 15d-15(e)
under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, as amended (Exchange Act) were
effective as of December 31, 2005 to ensure that information required to be
disclosed by the Company in reports that it files or submits under the Exchange
Act is (i) recorded, processed, summarized and reported within the time periods
specified in the Securities and Exchange Commission rules and forms and (ii)
accumulated and communicated to the Company&#146;s management, including its
principal executive officer and principal financial officer, as appropriate to
allow timely decisions regarding required disclosure.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-autospace:none;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="left" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Changes
in Internal Control Over Financial Reporting</font></i></p>

<p align="left" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">There were no
significant changes in the Company&#146;s internal control over financial reporting
identified in management&#146;s evaluation during the first quarter of&#160; 2006 that have materially affected, or are
reasonably likely to materially affect, the Company&#146;s internal control over
financial reporting.</font></p>

<p align="left" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">PART II.
OTHER INFORMATION</font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Item 1.
Legal Proceedings</font></b></p>

<p align="left" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company is
subject to various legal proceedings and claims that are discussed below. The
Company is also subject to certain other legal proceedings and claims that have
arisen in the ordinary course of business and which have not been fully
adjudicated. In the opinion of management, the Company does not have a
potential liability related to any current legal proceedings and claims that
would individually or in the aggregate have a material adverse effect on its
financial condition, liquidity or results of operations. However, the results
of legal proceedings cannot be predicted with certainty. Should the Company
fail to prevail in any of these legal matters or should several of these legal
matters be resolved against the Company in the same reporting period, the
operating results of a particular reporting period could be materially
adversely affected. The Company settled certain matters during the first
quarter of 2006 that did not individually or in the aggregate have a material
impact on the Company&#146;s results of operations.</font></p>

<p align="left" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Allen v. Apple
Computer, Inc.</font></i></p>

<p align="left" style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">On January 28,
2005 a plaintiff, filed a purported nationwide class action in Los Angeles
Superior Court alleging that a defect in the Company&#146;s 17-inch Studio Display
monitors results in dimming of half of the screen and constant blinking of the
power light. Plaintiff filed </font>an amended complaint on October 24, 2005, adding additional named
plaintiffs and expanding the alleged class to include purchasers of the 20-inch
Apple Cinema Display and the 23-inch Apple Cinema HD Display.&#160; The amended complaint alleges that the
displays have a purported defect that causes dimming of one-half of the screen,
and that the Company misrepresented the quality of the displays and/or
concealed the purported defect.&#160; Plaintiffs
assert claims under California Business &amp; Professions Code &#167;17200 (unfair
competition); California Business &amp; Professions Code &#167;17500 (false
advertising) and the Consumer Legal Remedies Act.&#160; The amended complaint seeks remedies
including damages and equitable relief.&#160;
On November 14, 2005, the Company filed an answer to the amended
complaint as to the allegations regarding the 17-inch display and a
demurrer/motion to strike as to the allegations regarding the 20-inch and
23-inch displays on the ground that plaintiffs failed to allege that they
purchased those displays.&#160; At a status
conference on November 1, 2005, the Court ordered Plaintiffs to amend their
complaint.&#160;&#160; Plaintiff filed an amended
complaint on December 12, 2005, and the Company answered on January 5, 2006
denying all allegations and asserting numerous affirmative defenses. The case
is in discovery. </p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></i></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Apple
Computer, Inc. v. Burst.com. Inc </font></i></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:0in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The
Company filed an action for declaratory judgment against Defendant Burst.com,
Inc. on January 4, 2006. The Company seeks declaratory judgment that U.S.
Patent Nos. 4,963,995, 5,164,839, and 5,995,705 are invalid and not infringed
by the Company.&#160; The patents allegedly
relate to methods and devices used for &#147;burst&#148; transmission of audio or video
files.&#160; Burst.com has claimed that iTunes,
iTunes Music Store, iPod, Airport Express, and Quicktime infringe the patents. </font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></i></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Apple
Corps&nbsp;Ltd. v. Apple Computer,&nbsp;Inc.; Apple Computer,&nbsp;Inc. v.
Apple Corps&nbsp;Ltd.</font></i></p>

<p align="left" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Plaintiff Apple
Corps filed this action on July&nbsp;4, 2003 in the High Court of Justice, Chancery
Division, in London alleging that the Company has breached a 1991 agreement
that resolved earlier trademark litigation between the</font></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">44</font></p>

<div align="left" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><hr size="2" width="100%" noshade color="gray" align="left"></div>

</div>
<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='44',FILE='C:\JMS\eudelhofen\06-3798-1\task790861\3798-1-ba-03.htm',USER='eudelho',CD='Feb  3 13:34 2006' -->


<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">


<div style="font-family:Times New Roman;">

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="left" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">parties regarding
use of certain Apple marks. Plaintiff seeks an injunction, unspecified damages,
and other relief. The Company filed a motion on October&nbsp;13, 2003,
challenging jurisdiction in the U.K.&#160; The
Court denied this motion on April&nbsp;7, 2004. The Company filed an appeal of
the Court&#146;s decision but subsequently withdrew the appeal.&#160; In November 2004, Plaintiff served the
Company with an Amended Bill of Particulars and on December 23, 2004, the
Company filed a Defence. On November 24, 2005, Plaintiff filed a Re-Amended
Bill of Particulars and the Company filed its Defence on December 16,
2005.&#160; Trial is set for the week of March
27, 2006.</font></p>

<p align="left" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="left" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">On October&nbsp;8,
2003, the Company filed a lawsuit against Apple Corps in the United States
District Court for the Northern District of California requesting a declaratory
judgment that the Company has not breached the 1991 agreement. Apple Corps
challenged jurisdiction in the California case but the Court denied that
challenge on March&nbsp;25, 2004. Apple Corps subsequently prevailed on a
motion to stay the California case during the pendency of the U.K. action. The
Company has dismissed the California lawsuit without prejudice. </font></p>

<p align="left" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Bader v.
Anderson; Bader v. Apple Computer, Inc. et. al.</font></i></p>

<p align="left" style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Plaintiff filed
this purported shareholder derivative action against the Company and each of
its current executive officers and members of its Board of Directors on May 19,
2005 in Santa Clara County Superior Court asserting claims for breach of
fiduciary duty, material misstatements and omissions, and violations of
California Businesses and Professions Code &#167;17200 (unfair competition).
Plaintiff alleges that the Company&#146;s March 14, 2005, proxy statement was false
and misleading for failure to disclose certain information relating to the
Apple Computer, Inc. Performance Bonus Plan, which was approved by shareholders
at the annual meeting held on April 21, 2005. Plaintiff, who ostensibly brings
suit on the Company&#146;s behalf, has made no demand on the Board of Directors and
alleges that such demand is excused. Plaintiff seeks injunctive and other
relief for purported injury to the Company. On July 27, 2005, Plaintiff filed
an amended complaint alleging that, in addition to the purported derivative
claims, </font>adoption of the
bonus plan and distribution of the proxy statement describing that plan also
inflicted injury on her directly as an individual shareholder.
Defendants filed a demurrer. On January 10, 2006, the court sustained
defendants&#146; demurrer and gave the Plaintiff 30 days to amend her
complaint.&#160; </p>

<p align="left" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="left" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Baghdasarian, et al. v. Apple Computer, Inc.</font></i></p>

<p align="left" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Plaintiffs filed this action in Los Angeles County Superior Court on
October 31, 2005, on behalf of a purported nationwide class of all purchasers
of all Apple wireless products (router, modem, or adaptor) sold at any
time.&#160; The complaint alleges that the
Company misrepresented the transmission rates of these products.&#160; The complaint alleges causes of action for
breach of express warranty and for violations of the Consumer Legal Remedies
Act, California Business &amp; Professions Code &#167;17200 (unfair competition) and
California Business &amp; Professions Code &#167;17500 (false advertising).&#160; The complaint seeks damages and equitable
remedies.&#160; The Company filed an answer
denying all allegations and asserting numerous affirmative defenses to the
complaint on December 15, 2005.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></i></p>

<p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-autospace:none;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Birdsong v. Apple Computer, Inc.</font></i> (filed
January 30, 2006, United States District Court for the Western District of
Louisiana);<i><font style="font-style:italic;"> Patterson v. Apple Computer, Inc.</font></i>
(filed January 31, 2006, United States District Court for the Northern District
of California)</p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:justify;text-autospace:none;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">These federal court complaints allege that the Company's iPod music
players, and the ear bud headphones sold with them, are inherently defective in
design and are sold without adequate warnings concerning the risk of
noise-induced hearing loss by iPod users.&nbsp; The<i><font style="font-style:italic;"> Birdsong</font></i>
action was brought on behalf of a purported Louisiana class of iPod purchasers
and alleges violations of the Louisiana Products Liability Act, breaches of
implied warranties, unjust enrichment and negligent misrepresentation.&nbsp;
The<i><font style="font-style:italic;"> Patterson</font></i> action was brought on behalf
of a purported class of all iPod purchasers within the four year period before
January 31, 2006.&nbsp; That action alleges breaches of implied and express
warranties, violations of California Business &amp; Professions Code &#167;17200 (unfair
competition), California Business &amp; Professions Code &#167;17500 (false advertising),
California Civil Code &#167;1750 (Consumer Legal Remedies Act), breaches of express
and implied warranties, negligent misrepresentation and unjust enrichment. The
Company has not yet been served with these actions and the Company&#146;s responses
to these complaints are not yet due.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:justify;text-autospace:none;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:justify;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">A similar complaint,<i><font style="font-style:italic;"> Royer-Brennan v. Apple
Computer, Inc. and Apple Canada, Inc.,</font></i> was filed in Montreal,
Quebec, Canada, on February 1, 2006, seeking authorization to institute a class
action on behalf of iPod purchasers in Quebec.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></i></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Branning et
al. v. Apple Computer, Inc.</font></i></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-autospace:none;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Plaintiffs
originally filed this purported class action in San Francisco County Superior
Court on February 17, 2005. The initial complaint alleged violations of
California Business &amp; Professions Code &#167;17200 (unfair competition) and
violation of the Consumer Legal Remedies Act (CLRA) regarding a variety of
purportedly unfair and unlawful conduct including, but not limited to,
allegedly selling used computers as new and failing to honor warranties.&#160; Plaintiffs also brought causes of action for
misappropriation of trade secrets, breach of contract, and violation of the
Song Beverly Act.&#160; Plaintiffs requested
unspecified damages and other relief.&#160; On
May 9, 2005, the Court granted the Company&#146;s motion to transfer the case to
Santa Clara County Superior Court. On May 2, 2005, Plaintiffs filed an amended
complaint adding two new named plaintiffs and three new causes of action
including a claim for treble damages under the Cartwright Act (California
Business and Professions Code &#167;16700 et seq.) and a claim for false
advertising. The Company filed a demurrer to the amended complaint, which the
Court sustained in its entirety on November 10, 2005. The Court granted
Plaintiffs leave to amend and they filed an amended complaint on December 29,
2005. &nbsp;Plaintiffs&#146; amended complaint adds three additional plaintiffs and
alleges many of the same factual claims as the previous complaints such as
alleged selling of used equipment as new, alleged failure to honor warranties
and service contracts for the consumer plaintiffs, and alleged fraud related to
the opening of the Apple Retail stores. &nbsp; Plaintiffs continue to assert
causes of action for unfair competition (&#167;17200), violations of the CLRA,
breach of contract, misappropriation of trade secrets, violations of the
Cartwright Act and allege new causes of action for fraud, conversion and breach
of the implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing. &nbsp;The Company filed
a demurrer to the amended complaint on January 31, 2006.</font></p>

<p align="left" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">&nbsp;</font></i></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">45</font></p>

<div align="left" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><hr size="2" width="100%" noshade color="gray" align="left"></div>

</div>
<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='45',FILE='C:\JMS\eudelhofen\06-3798-1\task790861\3798-1-ba-03.htm',USER='eudelho',CD='Feb  3 13:34 2006' -->


<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">


<div style="font-family:Times New Roman;">

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="left" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Butzer, et al.,&nbsp;v. Apple Computer, Inc./Wirges v. Apple Computer,
Inc. </font></i></p>

<p align="left" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Plaintiffs filed the Butzer action on August&nbsp;23, 2005, in the
United States District Court for the Northern District of California, San Jose
Division, on behalf of a purported nationwide class of all purchasers of the
Company&#146;s PowerBook G4 portable computers.&#160;
The complaint alleges defects in the memory of the computers.&#160; The complaint alleges that this purported
defect extends to other series of the Company&#146;s portables and states that
plaintiffs reserve the right to amend the complaint to include these other
series.&#160; Plaintiffs assert claims for
alleged violations of California Business &amp; Professions Code &#167;17200 (unfair
competition), California Business &amp; Professions Code &#167;17500 (false
advertising), the Consumer Legal Remedies Act and the Song-Beverly Consumer
Warranty Act.&#160; The complaint seeks
remedies including restitution and/or damages and injunctive relief.&#160; The Wirges action was filed on January 20,
2006 in the United State District Court for the Eastern District of Arkansas,
also on behalf of a purported nationwide class, and makes similar allegations.
Plaintiffs assert claims for breach of warranties, violation of Magnuson&#150;<a name="OLE_LINK2">Moss Act</a>, strict products liability and unjust enrichment.
The complaint seeks restitution, damages and other remedies. The Company filed
an answer to the Butzer complaint on October 19, 2005 denying the material
allegations and asserting numerous affirmative defenses.&#160; A class certification hearing is set for June
23, 2006. The case is in discovery. The Company&#146;s response to the Wirges action
is not yet due.&#160; </font></p>

<p align="left" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Cagney v.
Apple Computer,&nbsp;Inc.</font></i></p>

<p align="left" style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Plaintiff filed
this purported class action on January&nbsp;9, 2004 in Los Angeles County
Superior Court, alleging improper collection of sales tax in transactions
involving mail-in rebates. The complaint alleged violations of California
Business and Professions Code&nbsp;</font>&#167;17200 (unfair competition) and sought restitution and other
relief. The Company filed an answer on February&nbsp;20, 2004, denying all
allegations and asserting numerous affirmative defenses. The Company filed a
motion to disqualify Plaintiff&#146;s counsel, which the Court denied. The Company
filed a petition for a writ of mandate with respect to this ruling and the
Court of Appeal issued an order to show cause as to why the writ should not
issue. Plaintiff&#146;s lead counsel subsequently withdrew.&#160; On February 17, 2005 the Court of Appeal
ruled that the trial court abused its discretion in failing to grant the
Company&#146;s motion to disqualify and ordered the trial court to disqualify both
of Plaintiff&#146;s law firms upon remand. The trial court issued the
disqualification order on May 12, 2005. On May 9, 2005 Plaintiff substituted
new counsel. The Company has obtained an opinion on the tax issue from the
State Board of Equalization. The parties have reached a settlement and the
matter is concluded. Settlement of this case did not have a material effect on
the Company&#146;s financial position or results of operation. </p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Clark v.
Apple Computer, Inc.</font></i></p>

<p align="left" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Plaintiff filed
this purported class action on February 2, 2005 in Santa Clara County Superior
Court alleging defects in the Company&#146;s &#147;yo-yo&#148; power adapters.&#160; Plaintiffs requested unspecified damages and
other relief.&#160; The parties reached a
tentative settlement in this matter.&#160; The
Court granted preliminary approval of the settlement on April 19, 2005 and on
January 10, 2006, the Court gave final approval of the settlement.&#160; The matter is concluded. Settlement of this
matter did not have a material effect on the Company&#146;s financial position or
results of operation.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Compression
Labs,&nbsp;Inc. v. Apple Computer,&nbsp;Inc., et al.; Apple v. Compression Labs,&nbsp;Inc.,
et al.</font></i></p>

<p align="left" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Plaintiff
Compression Labs,&nbsp;Inc. filed this patent infringement action on
April&nbsp;22, 2004 against the Company and twenty-seven other defendants in
the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Texas, Marshall
Division, alleging infringement of U.S. patent 4,698,672 (the &#145;672 patent).
Plaintiff alleges that the Company infringes the patent by complying with the
JPEG standard as defined by CCITT Recommendation T.81 entitled &#147;Information
Technology&#151;Digital Compression and Coding of Continuous Tone Still
Images&#151;Requirements and Guidelines.&#148; Plaintiff seeks unspecified damages and
other relief.</font></p>

<p align="left" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="left" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">On July&nbsp;2,
2004, the Company and several other defendants in the Texas action filed a
lawsuit in the United States District Court in Delaware against Compression
Labs, Inc. and two other companies, requesting a declaratory judgment of
non-infringement, invalidity, implied license, and unenforceability with
respect to the &#145;672 patent.&#160; Additional
actions regarding this patent have been filed in other jurisdictions. On
February 16, 2005, the Panel on Multi-District Litigation (MDL) granted a
petition filed by certain defendants, seeking coordination and transfer of all
of these cases to one court for pre-trial proceedings. The MDL Panel has transferred
all of the cases to the Northern District of California. The defendants in the
Texas and Delaware actions had filed motions to dismiss prior to the transfer
and both motions are still pending. A Markman hearing is set for February 13,
2006.</font></p>

<p align="left" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="left" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Contois Music Technology LLC v. Apple Computer, Inc. </font></i></p>

<p align="left" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Plaintiff Contois Music Technology &nbsp;(&#147;Contois&#148;) filed this action
on June 13, 2005 in the United States District Court for Vermont, alleging
infringement by the Company of U.S. Patent No. 5,864,868, entitled &#147;Computer
Control System and User Interface for Media Playing Devices.&#148; &nbsp;The
complaint, which was served on October 4, 2005, seeks</font></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">46</font></p>

<div align="left" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><hr size="2" width="100%" noshade color="gray" align="left"></div>

</div>
<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='46',FILE='C:\JMS\eudelhofen\06-3798-1\task790861\3798-1-ba-03.htm',USER='eudelho',CD='Feb  3 13:34 2006' -->


<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">


<div style="font-family:Times New Roman;">

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="left" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">unspecified damages and other relief. &nbsp;The Company filed an answer
on November 23, 2005 denying all material allegations and asserting numerous
affirmative defenses.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="left" style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Craft&nbsp;v.
Apple Computer,&nbsp;Inc.</font></i> (filed December&nbsp;23, 2003,
Santa Clara County Superior Court); <i><font style="font-style:italic;">Chin&nbsp;v. Apple
Computer,&nbsp;Inc.</font></i> (filed December&nbsp;23, 2003, San Mateo County
Superior Court); <i><font style="font-style:italic;">Hughes&nbsp;v. Apple Computer,&nbsp;Inc.</font></i>
(filed December&nbsp;23, 2003, Santa Clara County Superior Court); <i><font style="font-style:italic;">Westley&nbsp;v. Apple Computer,&nbsp;Inc.</font></i> (filed
December&nbsp;26, 2003, San Francisco County Superior Court); <i><font style="font-style:italic;">Keegan&nbsp;v. Apple Computer,&nbsp;Inc.</font></i> (filed December&nbsp;30,
2003, Alameda County Superior Court); <i><font style="font-style:italic;">Wagya&nbsp;v. Apple
Computer,&nbsp;Inc.</font></i> (filed February&nbsp;19, 2004, Alameda County
Superior Court); <i><font style="font-style:italic;">Yamin&nbsp;v. Apple Computer,&nbsp;Inc.</font></i>
(filed February&nbsp;24, 2004, Los Angeles County Superior Court); <i><font style="font-style:italic;">Kieta&nbsp;v. Apple Computer,&nbsp;Inc.</font></i> (filed July&nbsp;8,
2004, Alameda County Superior Court); <i><font style="font-style:italic;">Mosley v. Apple Computer,
Inc. </font></i>(filed June 23, 2004, Westchester County, NY)</p>

<p align="left" style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Eight separate
plaintiffs filed purported class action cases in various California courts
alleging misrepresentations by the Company relative to iPod battery life. The
complaints include causes of action for violation of California Business and
Professions Code </font>&#167;17200
(unfair competition), the Consumer Legal Remedies Action and claims for false
advertising, fraudulent concealment, and breach of warranty. The complaints sought
unspecified damages and other relief. The cases were consolidated in San Mateo
County and Plaintiffs thereafter filed a consolidated complaint.&#160; On August 25, 2004, the Company filed an
answer denying all allegations and asserting numerous affirmative
defenses.&#160; A similar complaint relative
to iPod battery life, <i><font style="font-style:italic;">Mosley v. Apple Computer,
Inc.</font></i>, was filed in Westchester County, New York on June 23, 2004
alleging violations of New York General Business Law Sections 349 (unfair
competition) and 350 (false advertising).&#160;
This case was stayed.&#160; The parties
reached a tentative settlement of all cases, and the court granted preliminary
approval of the settlement on May 20, 2005. The court entered an order granting
final approval to the settlement on August 25, 2005. An appeal challenging the trial court&#146;s approval of the settlement was
filed on October 24, 2005, but was subsequently withdrawn. The settlement is
now final. Settlement of this matter will not have a material effect on
the Company&#146;s financial position or results of operations. </p>

<p align="left" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="left" style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">A similar
complaint related to the iPod battery life, <i><font style="font-style:italic;">Lenzi&nbsp;v. Apple
Canada,&nbsp;Inc.</font></i> was filed in Montreal, Quebec, Canada, on June 7,
2005, </font>seeking
authorization to institute a class action on behalf of Generations 1, 2 and 3
iPod owners in Quebec. On February&nbsp;2, 2006, the Court dismissed
plaintiff&#146;s motion for authorization to institute a class action (motion for
certification).</p>

<p align="left" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="left" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Two similar complaints relative to iPod battery life, <i><font style="font-style:italic;">Wolfe v. Apple</font></i> and <i><font style="font-style:italic;">Hirst v. Apple</font></i>,
were filed in Toronto, Ontario, Canada on August 15, 2005 and September 12,
2005, respectively.&#160;&#160; Both actions define
the purported class as a national class consisting of all persons in Canada who
have purchased or who own an iPod.&#160;&#160; A
motion for certification of the class proceeding has been scheduled for the
Spring of 2006.</font></p>

<p align="left" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Davis&nbsp;v.
Apple Computer,&nbsp;Inc.</font></i></p>

<p align="left" style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Plaintiff filed
this purported class action in San Francisco County Superior Court on
December&nbsp;5, 2002, alleging that the Company engaged in unfair and
deceptive business practices relating to its AppleCare Extended Service and
Warranty Plan. Plaintiff asserts causes of action for violation of California
Business &amp; Professions Code </font>&#167;17200 (unfair competition), California Business &amp;
Professions Code &#167;17500 (false
advertising), breach of the Song-Beverly Warranty Act, intentional
misrepresentation and concealment. Plaintiff requests unspecified damages and
other relief. The Company filed a demurrer and motion to strike which were
granted, in part, and Plaintiff filed an amended complaint. The Company filed
an answer on April&nbsp;17, 2003 denying all allegations and asserting numerous
affirmative defenses. Plaintiff subsequently amended its complaint. On
October&nbsp;29, 2003, the Company filed a motion to disqualify Plaintiff&#146;s
counsel in his role as counsel to the purported class and to the general
public. The Court granted the motion but allowed Plaintiff to retain substitute
counsel. Plaintiff did engage new counsel for the general public, but not for
the class. The Company moved to disqualify Plaintiff&#146;s new counsel and to have
the Court dismiss the general public claims for equitable relief. The Court
declined to disqualify Plaintiff&#146;s new counsel or to dismiss the equitable
claims, but did confirm that the class action claims are dismissed. The Company
appealed the ruling and the case was stayed pending the outcome of the appeal.
The Court of Appeal denied the appeal on August 17, 2005, affirming the trial
court&#146;s decision. The Company filed a Petition for review with the California
Supreme Court, which was denied on November 23, 2005.</p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">European
Commission Investigation</font></i></p>

<p align="left" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The European
Commission has notified the Company that it is investigating certain matters
relating to the iTunes Music Store in the European Union (EU).&#160; The European Commission is investigating
claims made by Which?, a United Kingdom (UK) consumer association, that the
Company is violating EU competition law by charging more</font></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">47</font></p>

<div align="left" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><hr size="2" width="100%" noshade color="gray" align="left"></div>

</div>
<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='47',FILE='C:\JMS\eudelhofen\06-3798-1\task790861\3798-1-ba-03.htm',USER='eudelho',CD='Feb  3 13:34 2006' -->


<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">


<div style="font-family:Times New Roman;">

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="left" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">for online music
in the UK than in Eurozone countries and preventing UK consumers from
purchasing online music from the iTunes Music Store for Eurozone
countries.&#160; The Which? claims were
originally lodged with the UK Office of Fair Trading, which subsequently
referred them to the European Commission.&#160;
The European Commission is investigating the charges under Articles 81
and 82 of the European Commission Treaty. </font></p>

<p align="left" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-autospace:none;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Gillis et
al. v. Apple Computer, Inc.</font></i></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Plaintiffs filed this purported
class action on December 23, 2005 in San Diego County Superior Court alleging
that the Company has misrepresented the hard drive capacity of two Powerbook G4
computers: the 12 inch, 1.5 GHz computer with 512 MB of memory and a 100GB hard
drive; and the 15 inch, 1.67 GHz computer with 1GB of memory and 100GB hard
drive. Plaintiffs allege that the Company&#146;s standard disclosure on its
packaging regarding hard drive size was not present on the packaging for these
two models. The complaint alleges violations of the California Business &amp;
Profession Code sections &#167;17200 (unfair competition), California Business &amp;
Profession Code &#167;17500 (false advertising), the Consumer Legal Remedies Act,
and causes of action for deceit and negligent misrepresentation. Plaintiffs
seek restitution and other relief. &nbsp;The Company&#146;s response is not yet due.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></i></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Gobeli
Research&nbsp;Ltd.&nbsp;v. Apple Computer,&nbsp;Inc., et al.</font></i></p>

<p align="left" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Plaintiff Gobeli
Research&nbsp;Ltd. filed this patent infringement action against the Company
and Sun Microsystems,&nbsp;Inc. on April&nbsp;15, 2004 in the United States
District Court for the Eastern District of Texas, Marshall Division, alleging
infringement of U.S. patent 5,418,968 related to a &#147;System and Method of
Controlling Interrupt Processing.&#148; Plaintiff alleged that the Company&#146;s Mac OS
9 and Mac OS X operating systems infringe Plaintiff&#146;s patent. Plaintiff sought
unspecified damages and other relief. The Company filed an answer on June 9,
2004, denying all material allegations and asserting numerous affirmative
defenses. The Company also asserted counterclaims requesting declaratory
judgment of non-infringement and invalidity.&#160;
A Markman hearing took place August 9, 2005, and the Court issued a
ruling on August 26, 2005 invalidating one of Plaintiff&#146;s two claims.&#160; On October 18, 2005, a Stipulation entered
into by the parties was filed removing Mac OS 9 from the case. The case settled
and was dismissed on January 13, 2006. Settlement of this matter did not have a
material effect on the Company&#146;s financial position or results of operations. </font></p>

<p align="left" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Goldberg,
et al. v. Apple Computer,&nbsp;Inc., et al. (f.k.a. &#147;Dan v. Apple
Computer,&nbsp;Inc.&#148;)</font></i></p>

<p align="left" style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Plaintiffs filed
this purported class action on September&nbsp;22, 2003 in Los Angeles County
Superior Court against the Company and other members of the computer industry
on behalf of an alleged nationwide class of purchasers of certain computer hard
drives. The case alleges violations of California Business and Professions Code
</font>&#167;17200 (unfair
competition), the Consumer Legal Remedies Act and false advertising related to
the size of the drives. Plaintiffs allege that calculation of hard drive size
using the decimal method misrepresents the actual size of the drive. The
complaint seeks restitution and other relief. Plaintiff filed an amended
complaint on March&nbsp;30, 2004 and the Company filed an answer on
September&nbsp;23, 2004, denying all allegations and asserting numerous
affirmative defenses.&#160; Defendants filed a
motion to strike portions of the complaint based on sales by resellers and
filed a motion for judgment on the pleadings based upon Proposition 64.&#160; The Court granted both motions at a hearing
on April 6, 2005.&#160; Plaintiff thereafter
filed an amended complaint on May 6, 2005. The Defendants filed a demurrer on June
6, 2005, which was heard on August 22, 2005. The Court granted the demurrer in
part and denied it in part. Plaintiff filed an amended complaint and the
Company filed an answer on December 15, 2005 denying all allegations and
asserting numerous assertive defenses.&#160; </p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Honeywell
International,&nbsp;Inc., et al.&nbsp;v. Apple Computer,&nbsp;Inc., et al.</font></i></p>

<p align="left" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Plaintiffs
Honeywell International,&nbsp;Inc. and Honeywell Intellectual
Properties,&nbsp;Inc. filed this action on October&nbsp;6, 2004 in the United
States District Court in Delaware alleging infringement by the Company and
other defendants of U.S. patent 5,280,371 entitled &#147;Directional Diffuser for a
Liquid Crystal Display.&#148; Plaintiffs seek unspecified damages and other
relief.&#160; The Company filed an answer on
December 21, 2004 denying all material allegations and asserting numerous
affirmative defenses. The Company has tendered the case to several suppliers.
On May 18, 2005 the Court stayed the case against the Company and the other
supplier defendants.&#160; Plaintiffs filed an
amended complaint on November 7, 2005 adding additional defendants and
expanding the scope of the accused products.&#160;
Given the stay, the Company&#146;s response to the amended complaint is not
yet due.</font></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">48</font></p>

<div align="left" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><hr size="2" width="100%" noshade color="gray" align="left"></div>

</div>
<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='48',FILE='C:\JMS\eudelhofen\06-3798-1\task790861\3798-1-ba-03.htm',USER='eudelho',CD='Feb  3 13:34 2006' -->


<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">


<div style="font-family:Times New Roman;">

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="left" style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">MacTech
Systems&nbsp;v. Apple Computer,&nbsp;Inc.; Macadam&nbsp;v. Apple
Computer,&nbsp;Inc.; Computer International,&nbsp;Inc.&nbsp;v. Apple
Computer,&nbsp;Inc.; Elite Computers and Software,&nbsp;Inc.&nbsp;v. Apple
Computer,&nbsp;Inc.; The Neighborhood Computer Store&nbsp;v. Apple
Computer,&nbsp;Inc.&#160; MacAccessory Center,
Inc. v. Apple Computer, Inc.; MacAccessory Center, Inc. v. Apple Computer, Inc.
</font></i>(all in Santa Clara County Superior Court)</p>

<p align="left" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Six resellers
filed similar lawsuits against the Company between late 2002 and early 2005 for
various causes of action including breach of contract, fraud, negligent and
intentional interference with economic relationship, negligent
misrepresentation, trade libel, unfair competition and false advertising.
Plaintiffs request unspecified damages and other relief. The Company answered
the Computer International complaint on November&nbsp;12, 2003, denying all
allegations and asserting numerous affirmative defenses. The Company filed an
answer in the Macadam case on December 3, 2004 denying all allegations and
asserting numerous defenses.&#160;&#160; Three of
the other plaintiffs filed amended complaints on February 7, 2005, and on March
16, 2005 the Company filed answers to these claims denying all allegations and
asserting numerous affirmative defenses.&#160;&#160;
A sixth Plaintiff, MacAccessory Center, filed a complaint on February
23, 2005.&#160; The Company filed an answer to
this complaint on April 20, 2005 denying all allegations and asserting numerous
affirmative defenses. &#160;All of these cases
with the exception of Macadam are in discovery and are coordinated (along with
the Branning class action) in Santa Clara Superior Court. The cases (except Branning)
are set for trial on November 27, 2006.&#160;
On December 19, 2005, Tom Santos, Macadam&#146;s principal and an original
plaintiff in the Macadam case, filed a Fifth Amended Complaint on his own
behalf (not on behalf of Macadam) alleging fraud, violations of <a name="OLE_LINK1">California Business &amp; Professional Code &#167;</a>17200 (unfair
competition), California Business &amp; Professional Code &#167;17500 (false
advertising) and the Consumer Legal Remedies Act. The Company filed a demurrer
to Santos&#146; amended complaint and a special motion to strike the defamation
cause of action on January 20, 2006. A hearing is scheduled for February 17,
2006. The Company also filed a cross complaint against Santos on January 20,
2006 alleging violations of California Business &amp; Professional Code &#167;17200,
fraud and deceit, breach of contract, and violation of California Penal Code &#167;502.</font></p>

<p align="left" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="left" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">On October&nbsp;1,
2003, one of the reseller Plaintiffs, Macadam, was deauthorized as an Apple
reseller. Macadam filed a motion for a temporary order to reinstate it as a
reseller, which the Court denied. The Court denied Macadam&#146;s motion for a
preliminary injunction on December&nbsp;19, 2003.&#160;&#160; On December 6, 2004 Macadam filed for
Chapter 11 Bankruptcy in the Northern District of California, which placed a
stay on the litigation as to Macadam only.&#160;
The Company filed a claim in the bankruptcy proceedings on February 16,
2005. &#160;The Macadam bankruptcy case was
converted to Chapter 7 (liquidation) on April 29, 2005. The Company has reached
a tentative settlement of the Macadam case with the Chapter 7 Bankruptcy
Trustee. The parties await approval of that settlement by the Bankruptcy Court.
</font></p>

<p align="left" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Macsolutions Inc. v. Apple
Computer, Inc.</font></i></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Plaintiff Macsolutions, Inc., an Apple
authorized reseller, filed this lawsuit against the Company on January 20, 2006
alleging breach of contract, fraud, misappropriation of trade secrets,
intentional interference with economic advantage, violation of the Cartwright
Act, violation of California Business &amp; Professions Code &#167;17200 (unfair
business practices) and fraudulent concealment. The factual allegations in this
complaint are similar to those in the six other reseller cases and the Branning
class action. Principally, Plaintiffs allege that the Company has treated
Macsolutions unfairly compared to other resellers, that the Company has
competed unfairly in opening the Apple Retail stores, and has allegedly sold
used goods as new. The Company's response is not yet due.</font></p>

<p align="left" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="left" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Premier International Associates LLC v. Apple Computer, Inc.</font></i></p>

<p align="left" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Plaintiff Premier International Associates LLC filed this action on
November 3, 2005 in the United States District Court for the Eastern District
of Texas, Marshall Division, alleging infringement by the Company of U.S.
Patents 6,243,725 and 6,763,345 both entitled &#147;List Building System.&#148;&#160; The complaint seeks unspecified damages and
other relief.&#160;&#160; The Company filed an
answer on January 13, 2006 denying all material allegations and asserting
numerous affirmative defenses.&#160; The
Company also asserted counter claims for a declaratory judgment of
noninfringement and invalidity. </font></p>

<p align="left" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Slattery v.
Apple Computer, Inc.</font></i></p>

<p align="left" style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Plaintiff filed
this purported class action on January 3, 2005 in the United States District
Court for the Northern District of California alleging various claims including
alleged unlawful tying of music purchased on the iTunes Music Store with the
purchase of iPods and vice versa and unlawful acquisition or maintenance of
monopoly market power.&#160; Plaintiff&#146;s
complaint alleged violations of </font>&#167;&#167;1 and 2 of the Sherman Act (15 U.S.C. &#167;&#167;1 and 2), California
Business and Professions Code &#167;16700
et seq. (the Cartwright Act), California Business and Professions Code &#167;17200 (unfair competition), common
law unjust enrichment and common law monopolization. Plaintiff seeks
unspecified damages and other relief.&#160;
The Company filed a motion to dismiss on February 10, 2005.&#160; On September 9, 2005, the Court denied the
motion in part and granted it in part. Plaintiff filed an amended complaint on
September 23, 2005 and the Company filed an answer on October 11, 2005. The
case is in discovery.</p>

<p align="left" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="left" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">St-Germain v. Apple Canada, Inc.</font></i></p>

<p align="left" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Plaintiff filed this case in Montreal, Quebec, Canada, on August 5,
2005, seeking authorization to institute a class action for the refund by the
Company of the Canadian Private Copying Levy that was applied to the iPod
purchase price in Quebec between December 12, 2003 and December 14, 2004 but
later declared invalid by the Canadian Court. A class certification hearing
took place January 13, 2006 and the Company awaits a ruling. The Company is in
the process of completing a refund program for this levy. </font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></i></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">49</font></p>

<div style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><hr size="2" width="100%" noshade color="gray" align="left"></div>

</div>
<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='49',FILE='C:\JMS\eudelhofen\06-3798-1\task790861\3798-1-ba-03.htm',USER='eudelho',CD='Feb  3 13:34 2006' -->


<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">


<div style="font-family:Times New Roman;">

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Teleshuttle
Technologies, LLC and BTG International&nbsp;Inc.&nbsp;v. Microsoft Corporation
and Apple Computer,&nbsp;Inc.</font></i></p>

<p align="left" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Plaintiffs filed
this case on July&nbsp;20, 2004 in United States District Court for the
Northern District of California alleging infringement of U.S. patent 6,557,054,
entitled &#147;Method and System for Distributing Updates by Presenting Directory of
Software Available for User Installation That is Not Already Installed on User
Station.&#148; Plaintiffs filed an amended complaint on September&nbsp;7, 2004,
adding a second patent, U.S. patent 6,769,009 entitled &#147;Method and System for
Selecting a Personalized Set of Information Channels.&#148; Plaintiffs seek
unspecified damages and other relief. The Company filed an answer on
October&nbsp;18, 2004, denying all material allegations and asserting numerous
affirmative defenses. On August 22, 2005, the Company filed an amended answer
to add charges of inequitable conduct. The case is in discovery.&#160; Markman briefing is completed. A technology
tutorial and Markman hearing are scheduled for March 2006. </font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></i></p>

<p align="left" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Tse v. Apple Computer, Inc. et al.</font></i></p>

<p align="left" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Plaintiff Ho Keung Tse filed this action against the Company and other
defendants on August 5, 2005 in the United States District Court for the
District of Maryland alleging infringement by the Company of U.S. Patent
6,665,797 entitled &#147;Protection of Software Again [sic] Against Unauthorized
Use.&#148;&#160; The complaint seeks unspecified
damages and other relief. The Company filed an answer on October 31, 2005
denying all material allegations and asserting numerous affirmative defenses.
On October 28, 2005, the Company and the other defendants filed a motion to
transfer the case to the Northern District of California.</font></p>

<p align="left" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="left" style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Wimmer v. Apple Computer, Inc. (</font></i>originally filed as<i><font style="font-style:italic;"> Tomczak v.
Apple</font></i>  <i><font style="font-style:italic;">Computer, Inc</font></i>. on October 19,
2005 in the United States District Court for the Northern District of
California, San Jose Division; amended complaint filed October 26, 2005); <i><font style="font-style:italic;">Moschella, et al., v.</font></i>  <i><font style="font-style:italic;">Apple Computer, Inc.</font></i>
(filed October 26, 2005 United States District Court for the Northern District
of California, San Jose Division); <i><font style="font-style:italic;">Calado, et al. v.</font></i>
<i><font style="font-style:italic;">Apple Computer, Inc.</font></i> (filed October 26,
2005, Los Angeles County Superior Court); <i><font style="font-style:italic;">Kahan, et al., v. Apple
Computer, Inc</font></i>. (filed October 31, 2005, United States District Court
for the Southern District of New York); <i><font style="font-style:italic;">Jennings, et al., v. Apple
Computer, Inc.</font></i> (filed November 4, 2005, United States District Court
for the Northern District of California, San Jose Division); <i><font style="font-style:italic;">Rappel v. Apple Computer, Inc.</font></i> (filed on November 23, 2005,
United States District Court for the District of New Jersey); <i><font style="font-style:italic;">Mayo v. Apple Computer, Inc.</font></i> (filed on December 7, 2005,
United States District Court for the Middle District of Louisiana); <i><font style="font-style:italic;">Valencia v. Apple Computer, Inc.</font></i> (filed on December 22,
2005, United States District Court for the Northern District of California); <i><font style="font-style:italic;">Williamson v. Apple Computer, Inc.</font></i> (filed on December 29,
2005, United States District Court for the Middle District of Louisiana)</p>

<p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-autospace:none;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">These federal
and state court complaints allege that the Company&#146;s iPod nano was defectively
designed so that it scratches excessively during normal use, rendering the
screen unreadable.&#160; The Wimmer and
Moschella actions were brought on behalf of purported nationwide classes of
iPod nano purchasers, with the exception of California purchasers, and allege
violations of the consumer protection, express and implied warranty statutes of
each state covered by the putative class definition, as well as negligent
misrepresentation and unjust enrichment under the common laws of these
jurisdictions. The Calado action was brought on behalf of a purported
California class of iPod nano purchasers and asserts claims for alleged
violation of California Business &amp; Professions Code &#167;17200 (unfair
competition), California Business &amp; Professions Code &#167;17500 (false
advertising), the Consumer Legal Remedies Act (CLRA), breaches of express and
implied warranties, negligent misrepresentation and unjust enrichment. The
Jennings action was brought on behalf of a purported class of all iPod nano
purchasers outside of the United States, based upon alleged violations of the
same California statutes as in the Calado complaint.&#160; The Kahan action was brought on behalf of a
purported New York class of iPod nano purchasers and alleges claims under the
New York unfair competition law, breach of express warranty and unjust
enrichment. </font>The
Rappel complaint is filed on behalf of a purported New Jersey class of
purchasers and alleges claims under the New Jersey Consumer Fraud Acts and for
breach of warranty and unjust enrichment. &nbsp;The Mayo and Williamson
complaints were both brought on behalf of a Louisiana class of purchasers, and
allege breach of warranties, unjust enrichment and violations of the Louisiana
Products Liability Act. The Valencia complaint was brought on behalf of a
worldwide class of purchasers and alleges breach of warranties, fraudulent
concealment, violations of California&#146;s Business &amp; Professions Code &#167;17200 and &#167;17500 and the CLRA, negligent misrepresentation and unjust enrichment. The
complaints seek damages and various other remedies.&#160; The Company&#146;s responses to these complaints
are not yet due. The Company filed a motion for transfer and consolidation
before Judicial Panel on Multi-District Litigation (MDL) to have all of the
federal cases transferred to the Northern District of California and
consolidated for pre-trial purposes. The motion is unopposed and the Company
awaits a ruling. Five of the actions are stayed pending a ruling on the Company&#146;s
MDL motion. The Company is seeking stays in the remaining actions.</p>

<p align="left" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="left" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Two similar complaints, <i><font style="font-style:italic;">Carpentier v. Apple
Canada, Inc</font></i>., and <i><font style="font-style:italic;">Royer-Brennan v. Apple
Computer, Inc. and Apple Canada, Inc. </font></i>were filed in Montreal,
Quebec, Canada, on October 27, 2005 and November 9, 2005, respectively,</font></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">50</font></p>

<div align="left" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><hr size="2" width="100%" noshade color="gray" align="left"></div>

</div>
<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='50',FILE='C:\JMS\eudelhofen\06-3798-1\task790861\3798-1-ba-03.htm',USER='eudelho',CD='Feb  3 13:34 2006' -->


<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">


<div>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="left" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">seeking authorization to institute class actions on behalf of iPod nano
purchasers in Quebec.&#160; A similar
complaint, <i><font style="font-style:italic;">Mund v. Apple Canada Inc. and Apple Computer, Inc.,</font></i>
was filed in Ontario, Canada on January 9, 2006 seeking authorization to
institute a class action on behalf of iPod nano purchasers in Canada.</font></p>

<p align="left" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Union
Federale des Consummateurs - Que Choisir v. Apple Computer France S.A.R.L. and
iTunes S.A.R.L.</font></i></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:0in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Plaintiff,
a consumer association in France, filed this complaint on February 9, 2005
alleging that the above-listed entities are violating consumer law by (1)
omitting to mention that the iPod is allegedly not compatible with music from
online music services other than the iTunes Music Store and that the music from
the iTunes Music Store is only compatible with the iPod and (2) allegedly tying
the sales of iPods to the iTunes Music Store and vice versa. &#160;Plaintiff seeks damages, injunctive relief and
other relief. The first hearing on the case took place on May 24, 2005. The
Company&#146;s response to the complaint was served on November 8, 2005. </font></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;text-indent:0in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">51</font></p>

<div style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><hr size="2" width="100%" noshade color="gray" align="left"></div>

</div>
<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='51',FILE='C:\JMS\eudelhofen\06-3798-1\task790861\3798-1-ba-03.htm',USER='eudelho',CD='Feb  3 13:34 2006' -->


<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">


<div>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Item 6. Exhibits</font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">(a) <b><font style="font-weight:bold;">Index to
Exhibits</font></b></font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%" style="border-collapse:collapse;width:100.0%;">

  <td width="9%" valign="bottom" style="border:none;border-bottom:solid windowtext 1.0pt;padding:0in 0in 0in 0in;width:9.6%;">

  Number</font></b></p>
  </td>
  <td width="2%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0in 0in 0in 0in;width:2.32%;">
  <p style="font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><b><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></b></p>
  </td>
  <td width="45%" valign="bottom" style="border:none;border-bottom:solid windowtext 1.0pt;padding:0in 0in 0in 0in;width:45.58%;">

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

  </td>
  <td width="2%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0in 0in 0in 0in;width:2.0%;">
  <p style="margin:0in -.5in .0001pt 0in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="46%" valign="top" style="padding:0in 0in 0in 0in;width:46.0%;">
  <p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">NeXT
  Computer, Inc. 1990 Stock Option Plan, as amended.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;text-indent:0in;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">SIGNATURE</font></b></p>

the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, the Registrant has duly caused this report
to be signed on its behalf by the undersigned, thereunto duly authorized.</font></p>

 </tr>
 <tr>
  <td width="48%" valign="top" style="padding:0in 0in 0in 0in;width:48.84%;">
  <p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="3%" valign="top" style="padding:0in 0in 0in 0in;width:3.5%;">
  <p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">By:</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="17%" valign="top" style="border:none;border-bottom:solid windowtext 1.0pt;padding:0in 0in 0in 0in;width:17.24%;">
  <p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">/s/ Peter
  Oppenheimer</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="30%" colspan="2" valign="top" style="padding:0in 0in 0in 0in;width:30.42%;">
  <p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr>
  <td width="48%" valign="top" style="padding:0in 0in 0in 0in;width:48.84%;">
  <p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="3%" valign="top" style="padding:0in 0in 0in 0in;width:3.5%;">
  <p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="20%" colspan="2" valign="top" style="padding:0in 0in 0in 0in;width:20.76%;">
  <p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Peter
  Oppenheimer</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="26%" valign="top" style="padding:0in 0in 0in 0in;width:26.9%;">
  <p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr>
  <td width="48%" valign="top" style="padding:0in 0in 0in 0in;width:48.84%;">
  <p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="3%" valign="top" style="padding:0in 0in 0in 0in;width:3.5%;">
  <p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="20%" colspan="2" valign="top" style="padding:0in 0in 0in 0in;width:20.76%;">
  <p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Senior Vice
  President and</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="26%" valign="top" style="padding:0in 0in 0in 0in;width:26.9%;">
